commentBody:
[[I’m gay. But I’ve never self-identified to a barber or the men in the shop. Nor have I seen any other man do the same. We should.]]

Dude, no one cares. I mean, if you consider the people in the barbershop to be personal friends, knock yourself out trying to socialize them. But otherwise, they are just stupid people you're sharing a space with for a period of time.

Maybe you should just find a different barbershop. Would you keep patronizing a bar where the staff used slurs? Would you even continue a cab ride if the driver started mouthing off with anti gay slurs?

Apparently a place called The Village Cuts is gay friendly.

Vote with your feet and your dollars.

And months from now when you run into one of the guys from your old barbershop and he asks why you stopped coming around, you can set him straight, pardon the expression.

replies.commentBody: I get the feeling Wesley Morris likes the barbershop to which he goes. Perhaps he gets something out of the comraderie there that makes tolerating the intolerance okay. Here's another thought. We live in a politically correct world, particularly in cities like New York. Perhaps this barbershop is the one place he can hear the unfiltered conversation of straight men who don't realize there is a gay man present. Maybe the knowledge is worth the pain.

Quit someone who gives great haircuts? Get serious. When I find someone who cuts my hair exactly as I like it, that person could be a ranging racist homophobic serial killer who pops his/her bubblegum and has a big poster of Justin Bieber on the wall. Mr. Morris is a gentleman who has his priorities in order!
